choices.text: Langerhans cells are dendritic cells which originate from reticuloendothelial system
Melanocytes are present in stratum basale
Keratin 5 and 14 is major keratin in the basal layer of epidermis
Stratum lucidum is sandwiched between stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the skin, except that ____.
questions.solution:
• Stratum lucidum is sandwiched between stratum corneum and stratum granulosum (GLC).
  • It is present only in the thick skin of the palms and soles.
  • It is also called as the clear cell layer due to the presence of refractile granules of Eleidin.
  • Melanocytes are present in stratum basale, originate from neural crest
  • Langerhans cells are dendritic cells which originate from bone marrow(RES).

questions.text: Chemical peeling is done by?
questions.solution:
1. Chemical peel produces a controlled partial thickness injury to the skin.
  2. Following the insult to the skin, process of wound healing process begins, regenerates epidermis from surrounding epithelium and adnexal structures, decrease solar elastosis, and replace and reorient the new dermal connective tissue
  3. It results in improved appearance and texture of the skin, with fewer rhytids
  4. Some peels like glycolic acid and TCA work well in pigmentation
  5. Salicylic acid, Resorcinol peels work in acne

Peeling Agents

  1. Glycolic acid.
  2. Jessner’s solution.
  3. Pyruvic acid.
  4. Resorcinol.
  5. Salicylic acid.
  6. Trichloracetic acid.

questions.text: Pruritus is seen in all except :
questions.solution:
Psoriasis is classically a non pruritic skin disease.

Infacts, few NO that you should remember in Ps.

No pruritus

No mucosal inv

No alopecia

Lichen simplex chronicus (LSC) is thickening of the skin with variable scale that arises secondarily to repetitive scratching or rubbing. Very itchy

Contact dermatitis is a cutaneous reaction to the application of an external allergen. Itching++

Lichen planus has 5Ps – pruritus is one of them

questions.text: After photo dynamic therapy lesion immediately becomes?
questions.solution:
Immediately after photodynamic therapy, some lesions may become red and edematous, which are usually transient symptoms and can be treated with topical steroids

Photodynamic Therapy

  1. Treatment modality used in the treatment of numerous malignant and premalignant conditions where photosensitising compounds are selectively absorbed by the affected tissues which are then targeted to visible light to cause destruction of the target lesion
  2. 5- Amino levulinic acid is commonly used as a photosensitiser
  3. The photosensitisers can be administered either systemically or topically, depending on the site of the growth
  4. Indications: Bowen's disease, Actinic Keratosis, SCC, BCC, Cutaneous metastasis of internal tumours, melanoma etc.

questions.text: Parapsoriasis can progress to which malignancy?
questions.solution:
Parapsoriasis

  1. Parapsoriasis refers to one of a group of skin disorders that are characterized primarily by their resemblance to psoriasis (red, scaly lesions), rather than by their underlying etiology.
  2. Red scaly plaques occur along the lines of cleavage on the trunk, aka langers lines
  3. Can progress to cutaneous T-cell lymphoma after latency of - 40 years.

questions.text: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome represents hemangiomas with-
questions.solution:
Combination of giant hemangioma, thrombocytopenia, and consumption coagulopathy

KMS is an infrequent but potentially fatal complication of rapidly growing vascular lesions in infants

The low platelet count in Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is due to a combination of increased destruction and sequestration of platelets within the expanding vascular tumour.

The tumor here is infantile haemangioma. MC vascular tumor in infants

choices.text: Most common site is neck and axilla

questions.text: Which of these is true about the lesion in the image (multiple choice)
questions.solution:
Skin tags (acrochordon)

  1. A common benign lesion composed of loose fibrous tissue and occurring mainly on the neck and major flexures as
  2. small soft pedunculated protrusion.
  3. Very common, particularly in women at the menopause or later.
  4. They are found to be associated with acanthosis nigricans, metabolic syndrome, obesity and diabetes
  5. Role of increased IGF1 postulated

Treatment :- cautery and cryotherapy

questions.text: Porphyria cutanea tarda can be treated by:
questions.solution:
1. Porphyria cutanea tarda is a group of disorders which are characterized by raised porphyrins in the plasma, urine and feces.
  2. Although it is usually acquired, it can also be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. When the disease is acquired, it is generally secondary to liver damage, most typically from alcohol abuse, dialysis
  3. Alcohol and estrogens may also precipitate autosomal dominant porphyria cutanea tarda.
  4. Patients typically have increased hair on the sides of the face and periorificial violaceous discolorations and blisters on the dorsum of the hands that leave scar after healing. (Wolverine facies)
  5. There is marked skin fragility in sun-exposed skin areas.
  6. Urine of these patients show a pink fluorescence under Wood's light.
  7. Patient should avoid alcohol and exposure to direct sun light.
  8. Venesection, the removal of 500 ml of blood every 2 weeks, results in remission - TOC
  9. Chloroquine – oral drug, acts as a systemic sunscreen and anti-inflammatory drug
  10. Patients with pseudo-porphyria secondary to dialysis are treated with erythropoietin in combination with venisection.

questions.text: Vesicles are never seen in
questions.solution:
The typical erythematous, non pruritic, maculopapular rash of measles begins at the hairline and behind the ears. It spreads down the trunk and limbs to include the palms and soles, and becomes confluent. VESicles are not seen in measles.

Viral fever with and without vesicles is a favourite question in AIIMS exam.

choices.text: Vesicle and bullae are not seen
Antiviral can be used for treatment
Associated with adverse reaction to drugs

questions.text: All the following are TRUE about this disease EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
Erythema multiforme - manifests as very characteristic 1-2 cm circular lesions consisting of a pinkish raised periphery and a dark blush centre thickened to the iris of the eye or the target of the shooting range. Such a lesions are therefore called iris lesions or target lesions

  1. Basically a type III immunologic reaction.
  2. Some case may develop tense blister at the centre of the target lesions due to the keratinocyte necrosis. No acantholysis.
  3. MC infectious cause – HSV 1 infection.
  4. Mycoplasma pneumoniae may trigger erythema multiforme major.
  5. Other causes – internal malignancies like leukemia, drugs, food additives

choices.text: Serum will be positive for anti-histone antibodies
Serum will be positive for Anti Musk antibodies
This patient also probably has a gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old diabetic and hypertensive man, who is on multiple oral medications, presents to the emergency department complaining of blistering of the skin. His major complaints are blisters on his arms, chest, and face and pruritus. On physical examination, he is afebrile. There are shallow crusted erosions, positive Nikolsky's sign. Scalp and mucous membranes normal. A skin biopsy reveals IgG on the surface of keratinocytes, and there is intraepidermal vesicle formation, beneath the stratum corneum. Also, there is history of fatigue and difficulty climbing stairs since 3 months Which of these statements is true regarding the disease this patient has?
questions.solution:
1. This patient has pemphigus foliaceus (PF), an autoimmune cutaneous disorder similar to pemphigus vulgaris (PV).
  2. PF is distinguished from PV by the fact that PF is a more superficial disorder than PV.
  3. The acantholytic blisters in PF are located high in the epidermis, usually just below the stratum corneum.
  4. In PF, mucous membranes are always spared. Fogo selvagem is the endemic form of PF.
  5. PF is associated with several autoimmune diseases; however, its association with thymoma and/or myasthenia gravis is most notable.
  6. This patient has symptoms suggestive of PF, associated with MG
  7. PF usually responds to topical or systemic glucocorticoids.
  8. PV is often associated with lymphoreticular malignant diseases such as lymphoma or Hodgkin’s disease.

choices.text: Genetic defect in the synthesis and maturation of tonofilament-desmosome complex
Antibodies against intercellular substance of epidermis absent

questions.text: Benign familial chronic pemphigus has the following features except-
questions.solution:
1. Familial benign pemphigus is a chronic autosomal dominant disorder
  2. Hailey-Hailey disease, or familial benign pemphigus, is hypothesized to result from a genetic defect in a calcium pump protein. The pump mutation is in ATP2C1, a gene localized on chromosome 3.
  3. This gene defect is similar to the genetic defect in Darier disease, which also is a calcium pump defect, ATP2A2.
  4. contributing factors are known that exacerbate the disease include heat, friction, and infection, resulting in separation of keratinocytes, especially in the intertriginous areas
  5. Familial benign pemphigus often manifests in the late teenage years or in adulthood (30s and 40s)
  6. vesicles and erythematous plaques with overlying crusts typically occur in the genital area, as well as the chest, neck, and axillary areas.
  7. Multiple asymptomatic longitudinal white bands on the fingernails also have been described
  8. Microscopic examination reveals intraepidermal and suprabasilar acantholysis, a dilapidated brick wall 
  9. Direct immunofluorescence in familial benign pemphigus is negative. The Nikolsky sign is negative, antibodies negative in blood

questions.text: Which of the following comorbid conditions is a relative contraindication for the use of oral agents for treating this disorder?
questions.solution:
1. Oral antifungal agents are required for effective treatment of dermaphytosis of the hair or nails.
  2. Treatment requires prolonged courses of drug and exposes the patient to an increased risk of adverse reaction to the drug. All of the oral anti-fungal agents carry a risk of hepatotoxicity.
  3. They should not be used in women who are pregnant or breast-feeding.
  4. Griseofulvin is approved for dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, or nails. Itraconazole and terbinafine are approved for onychomycosis.
  5. With terbinafine therapy, there is also a risk of drug-drug interaction with drugs that require the P450 enzyme for metabolism.

Most treatment courses require serial monitoring of liver enzymes to avoid drug-induced hepatitis or liver failure.

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden onset multifocal patchy alopecia. The dermoscopic finding is shown in the image below. The contact allergens found to be beneficial in the treatment of this disease include following except-
questions.solution:
The history of sudden onset patchy alopecia along with classical exclamation mark hair sign seen on the dermoscopic image are highly suggestive of alopecia areata as the diagnosis.

Contact immunotherapy is well documented treatment for alopecia areata, especially in patients with chronic/multifocal/resistant lesions. The contact allergens that have been used in the treatment of alopecia areata include dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB), squaric acid dibutylester (SADBE) and diphenylcyclopropenone (DPCP).

questions.text: A 25 year old male had arthritis in right ankle and multiple tender erythematous nodules on the shin. He also has fever and malaise for 2 weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Erythema nodosum (EN) (red nodules) is an inflammation of the fat cells under the skin (panniculitis) characterized by tender red nodules or lumps that are usually seen on both shins.
  2. EN is an immunologic response to a variety of different causes.
  3. Crops of tender subcutaneous nodules, associated with fever/malaise/arthritis.
  4. Most common seen in Anterior surface of legs/Shins
  5. Resolve in 2 - 4 weeks, with post inflammatory hyperpigmentation
  6. Never ulcerate (contrast with posterior leg and ulceration seen in erythema induratum)

Seen with streptococcal infection(MC infectious association), TB, Sarcoidosis, Drugs-OCP use, sulfonamides, Penicillin.

choices.text: Adhesive in the bindi is the main source of the chemical
Mono benzone ether of hydroquinone is present in high concentration in the glue
Melanocytes present but melanin absent in the patch

questions.text: Which of these is true about the disorder shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The sticker type of bindi is the main cause, and the causative agent is PTBP present in high concentration in the glue.

chemical is a known melanocytotoxic agent and depigmentation. No melanocytes in the lesion.

The treatment of bindi leucoderma hinges upon the early recognition of the condition (which is usually easy) and cessation of use of sticker bindis (which can be difficult)

PTBP can permanently destroy the melanocytes within a few days of continuous use.

Difficult to treat, topical steroids may help but ultimately, surgical methods needed.

questions.text: Child presents with linear verrucous plaques on the trunk with vacuolization of keratinocytes in s.Spinosum and s.Granulosum. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Vacuolization of keratinocytes: epidermolytic hyperkeratosis

  1. Linear verrucous plaque at birth: Epidermal nevus
  2. Incontinenta pigmenti: do not see vacuolisation
  3. Inflammatory linear verrucous epidermal nevus (ILVEN) presents as erythematous and verrucous papules, which are arranged in a linear array.
  4. The lesions are characteristically pruritic. ILVEN is usually unilateral and is frequently located on an extremity.
  5. Children are most commonly affected (girls more often than boys), often prior to the age 2. Clinically, ILVEN must be distinguished from other epidermal nevi, linear psoriasis, and lichen striatus.
  6. Unlike linear epidermal nevus, ILVEN is characteristically erythematous and pruritic.
  7. ILVEN is often difficult to treat and presents in early childhood.
  8. ILVEN is pruritic and does not spontaneously regress, which often occurs in lichen striatus

choices.text: A hamartoma of eccrine sweat gland

questions.text: A 25 year old lady presented with aymptomatic lesions around the eye. What is the pathology of this disorder
questions.solution: Syringoma is benign neoplasm with differentiation towards eccrine acrosyringium. Histologically ‘tadpole’ like morphology of tumour lobules present.

questions.text: A child presents with solitary white well defined patch on his right thigh. Diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
1. Information is this question are :-
    1. Lesion is on thigh
    2. Unilateral lesion (Isolated lesion on Right thigh)
  2. Both these suggest Nevus achromicus, i.e. Nevus acromicus involves :-
    1. Trunk and proximal extremity (thigh in this question)
    2. Lesion is unilateral
  3. Also keep in mind that, though Nevus achromicus presents since birth, it may be missed at birth and the patient may present in childhood (as in this question).

About other options

  1. Piebaldism involves extremity bilaterally symmetrical and there is characteristic white forelock which cannot be missed at birth.
  2. In albinism there is diffuse hypopigmentation of skin and hair throughout the body which cannot be missed at birth.

Acral vitiligo, as the name suggests involves acral areas (finger, toes, palms and soles).

questions.text: A 20 year old boy presents with asymptomatic skin lesions on the upper back. A test done in a dark room shows pale yellow color. The results from another bedside test are shown below. Which of the following is given for the treatment
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic skin lesions, with positive pale yellow fluorescence on woods lamp examination done in a dark room and the KOH scraping showing typical sphaghetti and meatball appearance is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor as the diagnosis.

Treatment

  1. Systemic azoles (ketoconazale, fluconazole or itraconazolE. provide a convenient therapeutic option.
  2. Topical antifungals are also effective; Azoles (clotrimazole, econazole, miconazole, ketoconazolE., selenium sulfide, sodium thiosulfate, Whitefield’s ointment (3% salicylic acid + 6% Benzoic aciD..
  3. Griscofulvin & terbinafine – No role in treatment of P. versicolor

questions.text: A 69 year old patient with long standing diabetes mellitus presented with asymptomatic, shiny, yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques with 2 tiny ulcerations. Which is the major site on the body where you find these lesions?
questions.solution:
Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is asymptomatic.

Patients usually present with shiny, asymptomatic patches that slowly enlarge over months to years. The patches are initially red-brown and progress to yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques. Ulcerations can occur, typically after trauma and occasionally with associated pain. The patient's main complaint is the unsightly cosmetic appearance of the lesions.

Most cases of necrobiosis lipoidica occur on the pretibial area

main findings on histopathology – granulomas, thickening of the blood vessel walls and endothelial cell swelling found in the middle to deep dermis, characteristics shared with diabetic microangiopathy.

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis was started on some treatment by a local practioner. He developed generalized pustules all over his body after stopping treatment. What is the treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
Pustular psoriasis is chracterised by appearance of multiple sterile pustules along with constitutional symptoms.One of the precipitating factor for pustular psoriasis to develop is withdrawal of systemic corticosteroid.

1st line of therapy is etretinate/acitretin, but Methotrexate and cyclosporine are also effective.

questions.text: Psoralen + ultraviolet therapy is useful in (multiple choice)
questions.solution:
1. Psoriasis: PUVA is a combination of oral or topical psoralen and ultraviolet A treatments twice a week for several months are required for resolution of severe 
  2. Generalized vitiligo occasionally responds to PUVA therapy. It may take 30 weeks of twice weekly treatments to achieve the response.
  3. Mycosis fungoides: Ultraviolet B or PUVA is helpful in producing improvement in parapsoriasis en plaque and early patch or plaque stage mycosis fungoides.
  4. If lesions are less than a few mm thick PUVA may also produce good response.
  5. Atopic dermatitis when extensive and severe can be treated with NBUVB but not PUVA
  6. No role of phototherapy in SLE which is infact a photosensitive disorder.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image. Considering the treatment she will receive, which of the adverse effects of the drug needs to be monitoring?
questions.solution:
1. Due to the well-known teratogenic effects of retinoic acid derivatives, all patients must be enrolled in a program designed to prevent pregnancy before initiation of a treatment regimen.
  2. Moreover, negative pregnancy tests must be obtained prior to each prescription refill. In addition, patients with a personal or family history of hypertriglyceridemia or a personal history of diabetes should be cautioned about the risks of hypertriglyceridemia and poor glucose control.
  3. Serum triglycerides should be followed during therapy.
  4. Concerns regarding a link between isotretinoin use and developing depression have not been proven.
  5. Tooth discoloration is a risk in children who receive tetracycline or related antibiotics. Wash out period of isotretinoin from fats is 1 months.

questions.text: Not a histological feature of lichen planus is -
questions.solution:
Histopathology in Lichen planus

  1. The basic pathology in lichen planus is the damage to the basal cell layer of epidermis leading to hydropic degeneration of basal cells.
  2. Epidermal thickening 'especially of granular cell layer->Hypergranulosis.
  3. Hyperkeratosis (Thickening of stratum corneum)
  4. Acanthosis(Thickening of Stratum) malpighii.
  5. Subepidermal - lichenoid band due to deposition of lymphocytes & histiocytes in upper dermis.
  6. Dropping of melanin pigment from damaged keratinocytes of epidermis into dermis ->pigment incontinence.
  7. This melanin is engulfed by macrophages which results information of cytoid bodies (civatte or colloid bodies).
  8. Max Joseph Histological cleft ->Separation of epidermis in small clefts.

questions.text: Which of these is a known association with this disease?
questions.solution:
The exact etiology of Pityriasis rosea is not known, but it is considered to be a viral disease; Human herpes virus-6

(HHV-6) and human Herpes virus-Z (HHV-7) may play a role.

questions.text: Minor clinical feature in diagnosis of atopic dermatitis A/E -
questions.solution:
1. Pruritis is a major criteria (not minor).
  2. Other major criteria are family history of atopy, typical morphology & distribution, chronicity.

questions.text: A 55 year old farmer, with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed severe itchy rash on face, arms and legs. The most appropriate drug for his treatment would be -
questions.solution:
Treatment of Allergic contact dermatitis

  1. Topical corticosteroids in combination with oral antihistaminics are effective in most cases.
  2. Extensive contact dermatitis may require treatment with a short course of oral corticosteroids.
  3. In air-borne contact dermatitis, azathioprine may be effective, especially as a steroid sparing agent in patients with contraindications to steroid therapy

As corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with DM and hypertension, best option here would be azathioprine.

Diagnosis: patch test, reading at 24 hr, 48 hr

questions.text: An 8 month old child presented with itchy exudative vesiculopustular lesions on the face, palm and soles, The siblings also have similar complaints, The treatment of choice is -
questions.solution:
1. Clinical presentation suggests diagnosis is scabies
  2. Topical permethrin is safe for children above 2 months of age and pregnant patients
  3. 5% permethrin cream is less toxic than the once commonly used 1 % lindane preparations and is effective against lindane-tolerant infestations
  4. Lindane is absorbed through the skin and its overuse has led to seizures and aplastic anemia so it is contraindicated in pregnant women or infants

Scabies in adults spares face and palms, soles but not in infants.

questions.text: Farmer with single warty indurated lesion on dorsum of foot. Which of the following could be the lesion?
questions.solution:
TBVC is a form of TB seen in India with a verrucous plaque on exposed trauma prone site seen in farmers

Verruca = Seen on the soles

Mycetoma+ is a swelling not a verrucous plaque

LP= is itchy
Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis

Definition:

  1. It’s a verrucous (wart like) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  2. Synonymous - warty tuberculosis, prosecutors wart, post primary inoculation tuberculosis
  3. It occurs when the skin of a previously infected or BCG-immunized host, possessing a moderate or high degree of immunity, is subjected to exogenous
  4. Reinoculation occurs at sites of minor abrasions or wounds.
  5. It commonly occurs in physicians, pathologists, medical students, laboratory attendants, Veterinarians, farmers, and butchers (tuberculous cattle).
  6. Lesions most commonly occur on the hands and, in children, the lower extremities. Infection starts as an asymptomatic warty papule. Slow growth and irregular peripheral extension occur.
  7. Pus and keratinous material may extrude from the fissures.
  8. Lesions usually are solitary, and regional nodes are not affected unless secondary bacterial infection occurs.
  9. Histology shows pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia with marked hyperkeratosis and a dense inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils and lymphocytes.

questions.text: A patient with a severe tinea pedis develops thickened and opacified nails on the right hand. The left hand fingernails are affected to a lesser degree. The nails have become discolored and have significant debris under the nail. Nail scrapings from the fingernails are most likely to grow which organism?
questions.solution:
1. Dermatophytes that commonly infect the skin, hair, and nails include members of the genera Trichophyton, Epidermophyton, and Microsporum.
  2. Tinea pedis is commonly associated with tinea manuum, unguium, or cruris (dermatophytosis of the hands, nails, or groin, respectively).
  3. Scratching the foot with the hand is a common mode of spreading the infection.
  4. Malassezia spp. is the pathologic agent in tinea versicolor and is thought to be pathogenic in seborrheic dermatitis.
  5. Candidal onychomycosis usually occurs only in the immunocompromised host or with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

choices.text: Three applications of gamma benzene hexachloride

questions.text: For Vagabonds disease, the treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
1. Pediculosis corporis (Vagabond's disease) lives on the undersurface of clothing and to which it attaches its eggs.
  2. The 'necks' of the garments and their seams are the most favored sites. The life of the adult is about 4 weeks and during this time a female will lay 200-300 eggs. It lives on the underclothing and 'visits' the skin only for food.
  3. That is why it tends to bite those areas which are in close contact with underclothes (upper part of shoulders and upper part of buttocks)
  4. The linear scratch marks caused by itching are very characteristic and are sufficient for diagnosis (Morbus errorum).
  5. Treatment is directed towards disinfecting all the clothes and not to the patient. The clothes should be either boiled or insufflated with 5% DOT powder or 1% gamma benzene hexachloride or 0.25% malathion.
  6. The excoriations on the trunk should be treated with application of calamine lotion or topical corticosteroids with an antibiotic along with a systemic antihistaminic for pruritus.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with uncontrolled sugars came for follow up in the medicine clinic. On examination, he was found to have hyperpigmented scaly macules in the axilla. The patient was not aware of the presence of these lesions. You send a few investigations. The culture will grow which organism :
questions.solution:
1. Erythrasma is a superficial infection of the skin, most typically in the skin folds and is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  2. A well demarcated brown discoloration with fine superficial scale is located in the skin folds, such as the submammary skin and groin.
  3. When examined under Wood's light, it shows coral-red fluorescence.
  4. Erythrasma responds well to topical azoles, e.g. clotrimazole and miconazole, as well as topical erythromycin cream, clindamycin and benzyl peroxide.

choices.text: A chronic scarring form of sycosis barbae

questions.text: Bockhart's impetigo refers to-
questions.solution:
1. Staphylococcus aureus superficial folliculitis (follicular impetigo of Bock-hart) is an infection of the follicular ostium with S. aureus.
  2. Use of topical steroids, especially of the stronger grades, is a predisposing factor

choices.text: Difficulty rising from a seated position

questions.text: The patient you are evaluating has had the rash on her face gradually grow over the last 6 weeks. She complains of only slight pruritus but is mostly concerned about her appearance. The lesions are not painful. Her past medical history is unremarkable. All of the following historic features are likely except
questions.solution:
1. Seborrheic dermatitis is a common skin disorder, for which the majority of patients lack any predisposing conditions.
  2. It is characterized by greasy scales overlying erythematous plaques or patches.
  3. The lesions are variably pruritic and may either improve or worsen with sunlight exposure.
  4. The most common location is the scalp, where it may manifest as severe dandruff.
  5. On the face, the most common locations are the eyebrows, eyelids, glabella, and nasolabial folds.
  6. Lesions typically worsen in the winter, and emotional stress also seems to exacerbate the rash.
  7. Seborrheic dermatitis is commonly seen in patients with Parkinson’s disease, facial nerve palsies, and HIV infection.
  8. The pathogenesis remains unclear but the yeast Malassezia furfur appears to play a role.
  9. Successful treatment with topical ketoconazole and the prevalence of the disease in immunocompromised patients suggests that the yeast is pathogenic.
  10. Patients with dermatomyositis may exhibit a heliotrope rash (violaceous rash around the eyelids) and may complain of proximal muscle weakness.

questions.text: Physical examination on a 65-year-old man with mild congestive heart failure reveals varicose veins, ankle edema, and inflammation of much of the skin near the ankles of both legs. The affected skin exhibits edema, erythema, mild scaling, and brown discoloration. The edges of skin involvement are poorly defined. On one ankle, a one centimeter diameter ulcerated area is seen within the erythematous area. The most likely diagnosis in this case is:
questions.solution:
It is stasis dermatitis which is defined as a common complication of chronic lower leg edema characteristically because of either venous incompetence, congestive heart failure or even both. Due to its relative lack of symptoms, both the physician as well as the patient may neglect the condition.

Treatment - properly fitted support stockings, raising the ankles above the heart. Bland dressings and compresses are useful in order to treat ulcers. Oral antibiotics are used in cases where an ulcer becomes infected.

Atopic dermatitis is an itchy inflammation of the skin that appears to have an allergic basis.

In Lichen simplex chronicus, there may be an involvement of ankles as well however the lesion is very itchy, tends to be relatively localized but it is not typically accompanied by ankle edema.

Seborrheic dermatitis leads to diffuse scaling (dandruff) of the scalp.

questions.text: Hyper extensibility with normal elastic recoil is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Collagen defects allow the hyperextensibility of skin and loose jointedness but skin bounces back because of normal elastin as in Ehlers Danlos syndrome.
  • However, in elastin defects like cutis laxa and pseudoxanthoma elasticum skin looses its elastic recoil and hangs in loose folds.
  • Scleroderma on the other hand is characterized by excessive abnormal collagen producing binding down of skin that is difficult to pinch and pick into folds.

questions.text: A patient gives a h/o recurrent oral ulcers. The ulcers are small with a yellow floor surrounded by an erythematous halo on the lips. He also has multiple, tender nodules on the shin. He most likely has
questions.solution:
Behcet’s syndrome-Behcet’s syndrome is an disorder of unknown etiology having strong association with HLA B51.

Its more frequently seen in age group 20-30 years having male preponderance.

Clinical features-

Its characterized by recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers

Ulcers have a necrotic floor surrounded by halo of erythema.

Other features include erythema nodosum like lesions(which are deep seated multiple tender nodules on shin area)

pathergy test- used for diagnosis of Behcet’s syndrome.

Positive pathergy performed with oblique insertion of a 20 guage needle and read by physician at 24-48 hours.)

Fixed drug eruption- these are characterized by well defined circular deeply erythematous plaques which sometimes develop central bullae.They subside leaving behind slate gray hyperpigmentation which persist btwn acute episodes. Lesions recur at same site each time the offending drug is taken usully after 8-16 hours after intake of drug. Drugs implicated  - barbiturates, sulphonamides, tetracyclines, salicylates and phenacetin.

Pemphigus vulgaris It is characterized by flaccid bullae appearing o normal skin which rupture to form painful erosions which have tendency to spread and take very long to re-epethialise. Nikolsky sign and Bulla spread sign are positive. IN 50% pts lesions begin in oral mucosa.eventually all pts develop mucosal lesions.oral mucosa is involved most frequently.Painful erosions which extend peripherally with shedding of the mucosa.

Herpes labialis- It is caused by HSV hominis type1.(HSV hominis has two antigenic types 1 and 2. Type 2 causes genital infection). HSV type1 infection is characterized by Acute gingivostomatitis(closely grouped vesicles which rapidly form polycyclic ulcers with a yellow psuedomembrane and heal in about a fortnight.). Malaise fever and lymphadenopathy are frequent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution: Painless oral ulcers are produced by SLE, however it is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: Fine reticular pigmentation with palmar pits are seen in:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Kitamura’s reticulate acropigmentation but that is not one of the choices. The next best answer is dowling degos disease. The relevant details are:

  • DOWLING-DEGOS DISEASE : autosomal dominant condition caused by loss of function mutations in the keratin 5 gene (KRT5) usually presents postpubertally with asymptomatic, symmetrical, progressive, reticulate pigmentation of the flexures like axillae and groins.

Nails and hair are normal.

Other features - pitted acneiform scars near the angles of the mouth.

The histology is diagnostic, with a distinctive form of acanthosis characterized by an irregular elongation of thin branching rete ridges, with a concentration of melanin at the tips with melanocyte count being normal. (Deer antlers)

 

  • RETICULATE ACROPIGMENTATION OF KITAMURA: Reticulate acropigmentation of Kitamura is characterized by a reticulate pigmentation on the dorsa of the hands, palmar pits and breakages of epidermal ridge pattern are found.
  • SYMMETRICAL DYSCHROMATOSIS OF THE EXTREMITIES: RETICULATE ACROPIGMENTATION OF DOHI: Symmetrical dyschromatosis of the extremities is an autosomal dominant disorder with mottled pigmentation and depigmentation on the dorsa of the hands and feet and sometimes on the arms and legs.
  • BLOOM SYNDROME is transmitted as an autosomal-recessive trait in Jews, characterized by photosensitive telangectatic erythema in the butterfly area of the face and dwarfism in the first 2 years of life. 
  • ROTHMUND - THOMSON SYNDROME (POIKILODERMA CONGENITALE): Rothmund-Thomson syndrome is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder. Poikiloderma begins at 3 to 6 months of age, with tense, pink, edematous patches on the cheeks and other exposed sites (acute phase) followed by atrophy, reticulate pigmentation and telangectasia (chronic phase) typically involving the arms and legs are affected with sparing of the antecubital and popliteal fossae. 
  • COCKAYNE SYNDROME: Autosomal recessive condition with photosensitivity and neurological degeneration. It differs from Xeroderma pigmentosa by the lack of freckling and skin cancers and presence of dwarfism, beaked nose, and loss of subcutaneous fat, basal ganglion calcification, retinopathy and deafness. Cockayne described syndrome as dwarfism with retinal atrophy and deafness.

questions.text: Muehrcke lines are seen nails due to?
questions.solution: Paired parallel white bands that do not change position with growth of the nail and thus reflect a change in the nail bed are associated with hypoalbuminemia and are called Muehrcke lines.

questions.text: A 28 yr old lady has asymptomatic done shaped smell nodules on her forehead for the last two months. Her 2 year old daughter also has similar lesions. What is causative agent of the lesion?
questions.solution:
1. Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a viral infection of the skin
  2. It is caused by a DNA poxvirus called the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV).
  3. The virus that causes molluscum contagiosum is spread from person to person by touching the affected skin. The virus may also be spread by touching a surface with the virus on it, such as a towel, clothing, or toys.
  4. Molluscum contagiosum lesions are flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and pearly in appearance. They are often 1–5 mm in diameter, with a dimpled center(umbilication).
  5. They are generally not painful, but they may itch or become irritated.
  6. Diagnosis is made on the clinical appearance
  7. Tzank – HP bodies
  8. Histologically, molluscum contagiosum is characterized by molluscum bodies in the epidermis above the stratum basale, which consist of large cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (accumulated virions) and a small peripheral nucleus.

questions.text: A smear was prepared from the genital ulcer. Identify the organism responsible?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi is a  fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus bacteria, which that causes chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterized by painful sores on the genitalia.

Chancroid starts as an erythematous papular lesion that breaks down into a painful bleeding ulcer with a necrotic base and ragged edge.

  1. Gram stain – rail road track/school of fish appearance
  2. ducreyican be cultured on chocolate agar, currently considered the 'gold standard' test.
  3. ducreyi gram stain appears as 'school of fish.'
  4. TOC - azithromycin

choices.text: Resistance to M. leprae is poor, large numbers of organisms are present and skin lesions are extensive.
Pregnancy is a recognized precipitating factor due to a relatively reduced immunity.
'Satellite papules' are often found adjacent to the main plaques in BT.
Loss of sensation in skin lesions is the rule and regional nerve involvement with enlargement and palsies is common.

questions.text: False about tuberculoid form of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Tuberculoid forms of leprosy

In tuberculoid forms of leprosy, resistance to M. leprae is high, small numbers of organisms are present and skin lesions are few, Histopathology of a skin biopsy reveals granulomatous inflammation, often showing neurotropism.

Pregnancy is a recognized precipitating factor for leprosy due to a relatively reduced immunity. In the post-partum period type I reactions (characterized by sudden enhanced inflammation of skin lesions and neuritis) can occur when normal immune function is restored.

In borderline tuberculoid leprosy satellite papules are often found adjacent to the main plaques.

Just go through the following table from HARRISON 17th Ed chapter 152

questions.text: Identify the lesion:
questions.solution:
1. The image show presence of Tuberous xanthomas.
  2. They are seen at pressure areas, such as the extensor surface of the knees, the elbows, and the buttocks.
  3. Tuberous xanthomas are firm, painless, red-yellow nodules. The lesions can coalesce to form multi-lobated tumors and can be extensive.
  4. They may rarely occur on the cheeks and nasal bridge.

questions.text: The given image is indicative of which clinical sign?
questions.solution:
Hutchinson's sign is the periungual extension of brown-black pigment from the nail bed and nail matrix onto the surrounding tissues, which usually occurs during the radial growth phase of subungual melanoma

Although a positive Hutchinson's sign should alert the clinician to the likelihood of a subungual melanoma, it is neither pathognomonic nor its absence precludes the diagnosis of melanoma.

questions.text: The sign eliciting deep dermal tenderness on pressing a syphilitic lesion is called as
questions.solution:
This is a sign to be elicited in case of secondary syphilis and cutaneous vasculitis, where there is deep dermal tenderness on pressing the lesion (e.g., papular lesions of syphilis) with a pinhead.

Signifies presence of end arteritis

Axillary freckling seen in type I neurofibromatosis is known as Crowe's sign

Shuster's sign

Scarring of the concha due to lesions of discoid lupus erythematosus is called as Shuster's sign and it can be present in 30% of the case

Love's sign

Exact localization of tenderness with the help of pin head in glomus tumor is called as Love's sign

questions.text: A child was born with thin translucent membranes around the body, covering his face, trunk, and extremities and had ectropion and eclabium. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Two most common types of skin disorders presenting as collodion at birth are non-bullous congenital erythroderma and Lamellar ichthyosis. Other less common pathologies responsible for this presentation include: Ectodermal dysplasia, Sjögren Larsen syndrome, Comel-Netherton syndrome Gaucher Disease type 2, Hay-Well syndrome, Trichothyodystrophy, Neutral lipid storage disease, etc.

Ichthyosis vulgaris-baby is normal at birth

questions.text: In which syndrome is the following condition seen?
questions.solution:
The most common skin lesions are hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf spots) that occur in more than 90% of patients with TSC.

Also the earliest lesions to appear

They are best visualized by Wood light.

Other cutaneous clinical features include forehead plaques, shagreen patch, and facial angiofibromas(adenoma sebaceoum)

Koenen fibromas develop in up to 50% of cases of TSC, with onset occurring around puberty.

These tumors range in size and can involve every digit. The feet are more commonly involved than the hands. The nodules are usually skin colored or reddish, arising from the nail bed.

Histologically, they are fibromas or angiofibromas

The presence of periungual fibromas is a major criterion in the diagnosis of TSC and, as in facial angiofibromas, it is nearly always pathognomonic for TSC

questions.text: A 25 year old young adult female presents with following lesions in axilla:
questions.solution:
1. The image shows presence of discrete skin colored dome shaped papules in the axilla just below the huge furuncle. The clinical diagnosis is Fox Fordyce disease.
  2. Hidradenitis suppurative presents with multiple blind boils with sinus tracts and recurrences in axilla, perineum and inguinal areas.
  3. Acne conglobata presents on face usually with nodulocystic acne and multiple interconnecting sinus tracts.
